challenges-to-voters-at-the-polling-plac.name: Challenges to Voters at the Polling Place

subtopics.fact: Any precinct official or any registered voter may challenge any voter.
Challenges are permitted at the polling place on Election Day.
subtopics.subtopic: What are the restrictions on polling place challenges?

subtopics.fact:
From Iowa Statutes:
  • The challenged person is not a citizen of the United States.
  • The challenged person is less than eighteen years of age as of the date of the election at which the person is offering to vote.
  • The challenged person is not a resident at the address where the person is
registered. [This is not a valid reason for voters who are correcting their address or registering to vote on Election Day.]
  • The challenged person is not a resident of the precinct where the person is offering to vote.
  • The challenged person has falsified information on the person's registration form or on the person's declaration of eligibility.
  • The challenged person has been convicted of a felony, and the person's voting rights have not been restored.
  • The challenged person has been adjudged by a court of law to be a person who is incompetent to vote and no subsequent proceeding has reversed that finding.
subtopics.subtopic: What are the allowed reasons on which a voter can be challenged?

subtopics.fact: No; however, challengers must swear an oath that their challenge is true. Knowingly making a false challenge is illegal.
subtopics.subtopic: Is there a requirement for the challenger to provide cause or evidence?

subtopics.fact: The poll worker will ask the challenged voter questions about their eligibility, and the voter will have the chance to provide proof of their qualifications. After that, the challenger may choose to withdraw their challenge. If not, the challenged voter must vote using a provisional ballot, and provide any necessary proof of their qualifications with the provisional ballot.
subtopics.subtopic: How does a voter defend their eligibility to vote if they are challenged?

subtopics.fact: Any voter *who is registering to vote on Election Day* must show proof of identification *and* proof of residency. Additionally, first-time voters who registered by mail, inactive voters and a few others may be asked to show ID.
subtopics.subtopic: Who must show ID to vote?

subtopics.fact:
A voter must show proof of their identity and where they live. The proof of ID can count as proof of residency as well if it shows the voter's current address. Proof of Identity includes:
  • Iowa driver's license
  • Iowa non-driver identification card
  • Out-of-state driver's license or non-driver identification card
  • U.S. passport
  • U.S. military ID
  • ID card issued by the voter's employer
  • Student ID issued by an Iowa high school or college
Proof of residence includes:
  • Utility bill (including a cell phone bill)
  • Bank statement
  • Paycheck
  • Government check
  • Other government document
Voters registering on Election Day may have another registered voter swear to their identity and residency in place of showing ID.
subtopics.subtopic: If a voter has no ID, are there alternatives such as an oath or witness?

subtopics.fact: Yes, a student ID issued by an Iowa college, university or high school is acceptable proof of identity. However, the voter will probably need to show additional documentation to prove their residency if their student ID does not list their address.
subtopics.subtopic: Is a student ID an acceptable form of identification?

citations: Per conversation with the Iowa Secretary of State's office on 8/30/2011
subtopics.subtopic: Does the ID have to show the address at which a voter is registered to vote?

subtopics.fact: No, ID requirements are the same for all elections.
